author: {'steamid': '76561198044078952', 'num_games_owned': 911, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 6680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5569, 'last_played': 1609567531}
review:
[h1] Solutions to Common Problems [/h1]

[u][b]How to fix your in-game DLC being unpurchased:[/b][/u]  Thank you to Nitrostriker for bringing this up, you can access the fix on the official paradox forums here: https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/majesty-2-collector-dlc-fix.983538/
Normally everything is unlocked in the collection version, so if something is still locked, ensure you have applied this fix.

[u][b]My game won't start, citing a missing file:[/b][/u]  Delete the resource.mod folder, then run installDLC.exe and installSampleMaps.exe (usually inside the support folder). Thank you to a discussions forum user for this fix, but I can no longer find the thread. In case this doesn't fix your issue, comment here and I can send you a zip of the working game files with all fixes applied.

[u][b]A possible reason the game is [i]too[/i] difficult:[/b][/u]  It seems like the game gets more difficult every year based on the reviews. This isn't necessarily your fault as a player since due to the game's age, it doesn't process frames over 60 very well. It will slow down your build times, and cause monster dens to produce units at exponentially higher rates. If your framerate is over 60, install a frame limiter or set a limit for the Majesty program in your graphics card's software. The game will still be difficult, but no more so than the devs intended. (it is unknown if this issue is present during multiplayer, since multiplayer doesn't utilize the same timescale as singleplayer)

[u][b]How to actually start up a multiplayer server:[/b][/u]  Hamachi is everybody's least favorite but functional option, though it doesn't interact well with Majesty. If you use this program, ensure you're running as an administrator. However, I would instead recommend you use "ZeroTier" which is like Hamachi if it were ever a good program. It's a little hard to set up, but leagues better overall (in performance, security, and privacy).

[h1] The Actual Review [/h1]

I know this game has been out for quite a while, but I'm mostly reviewing it to state it's [i]still[/i] worth getting. I have about 300 more hours from a DRM free version, so however many hours I have on here is not accurate.

If you're just curious about the "Collection" edition portion, it is worth the money based on the sheer amount of content added (ensure you apply the above DLC fix).

[b]For those who haven't played the first...[/b] (see below if you have played the first)

It isn't important that you have played the first, as there isn't really any important information to transfer to the second. If you have ever wanted to play an RTS in which you don't have to deal with managing [i]everything[/i] your units are doing, this is likely the game for you. It requires quick thinking (or average thinking at .2x speed) and some knowledge of each guild and building, but the main campaign eases you into the game at a pace that will teach you all you need to know. Many of the missions have unique side missions to make sure there's variation each time you play.

Certain missions can be very difficult and will require you to be entirely precise in your decisions at the start (such as the mission in the King Maker expansion that sends a bunch of dragonlings at you near instantly). Clerics and Dwarven towers will quickly become your best friends.

[b]For those who have played the first...[/b]

I've played the original majesty for likely 400+ hours, and I have a great fondness for it. However, I see a lot of the negative reviews and comments are based solely upon the original "being better". While I don't think this one is any better, I don't think it's any worse -- based on how great a game the first was, that's an achievement.

If you've played the first, you can expect to miss this... (cons)
[list]
[*] The tournament has been removed (my biggest negative)
[*] Heroes are harder to guide.
[*] No more naming of heroes.
[*] Mushrooms for poison have been turned into just an upgrade.
[*] Religious temples are now only able to be placed at set locations.
[*] A few other things.
[/list]

However, the additions make this one worth playing. (pros)
[list]
[*] The UI is much more intuitive
[*] 3D graphics (a bit dated now, but still fitting)
[*] Unnecessary buildings have been combined into others
[*] More guilds to choose from
[*] A few extra skills, including skills gained at certain levels per class.
[*] More intuitive spell system.
[*] Many more missions.
[*] Ability to play as the enemies in a special campaign mode (honestly my favorite expansion)
[*] Buildings don't completely catch fire when a rat bites it (who else was annoyed by this?)
[*] Heroes don't feel as squishy. (except for the mage. Expect them to still die every five seconds for their lower levels)
[*] A few other small things not worth mentioning
[/list]

[b]As for the difficulty...[/b] (including a few tips, skip if you dislike very minor spoilers)

Yes, this game is 0 to 100 on certain missions, but all of them are completely possible. You will [i]have to[/i] utilize the .2x speed button very frequently and will occassionally have to baby-sit your lower leveled heroes with the heal spell should they get into trouble.

If all else fails, you can usually go back to using two cleric guilds at the start. Clerics are the toughest unit in the game as long as you can keep them together, as they're nearly infinitely powerful as long as they have some mana. Shortly after, you will want to get dwarves for both the unit and especially the tower. One tower alone is enough to kill a werewolf or a dragon, which can easily level an entire settlement early on. By placing a normal guard tower behind each dwarven tower, you can often times keep a dwarven tower alive should other small enemies come with the big ones. 2 dwarven towers and 1 upgraded guard tower should be all you ever need in a choke point (barring a couple obvious exceptions).

When it comes to temples, Krypta should be your first priority -- they stay alive longer, deal more damage, and have a greater range than almost any unit in the game (some are better in one aspect, but lack the other two). Agrela (ressurection spell) and Lunord (massive single target DPS) are also both great options.

Now, a few quick general tips. Do not forget to use inns, as they will often save your heroes. While it's tempting, don't always destroy every nearby monster nest -- heroes level much slower when "indestructable" nests are all that remain. Even in a semi-hostile area, it's usually always worth it to build and rebuild trading posts. Last but not least, micromanage your economy early on -- in addition to leveling your castle and market early on, build a potion bazaar as soon as possible (it pays for itself rather quickly without any potions researched).

If you'd like any more tips or suggestions, feel free to ask in the comments or add me.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

All in all, I feel this one is a more full game than the first. There are some noticeable changes, but for the most part, it's just something to get used to rather than miss intensely. This game is worth your time and will immerse you faster than you might expect.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990707820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2101, 'last_played': 1675300978}
review:
I'm writing this review because It bothers me how little notoriety majesty gets

Majesty 1 and Majesty 2 are both incredibly entertaining games that have value that long outlives their price point. Don't let my hours played fool you. I owned these games before steam was so common place and have likely sunk over 100 hours into Majesty 1 and at least 70 or so into Majesty 2.

But what is the game like? Well, Majesty is an RTS game yes, but it is best described as being god of your own little fantasy MMORPG. Your units in the game act on their own free will, and you must tempt them to do deeds for the kingdom by setting up quests for them to accomplish in the game by way of bounties. It's an unusual system, that can occassionally be difficult to get the hang of, but once you do it feels natural.

Like players in an MMO your units will level up, learn skills, & go to the shops and buy potions, weapons, armor, and whatever magic trinkets your market might have for sale. One of them might even get lucky and come across an extremely powerful weapon early in the game and go on to become a powerful lord of your land, valliantly defending against hordes of creatures that instantly wipe out your younger units, giving them breathing room to grow in power.

I could ramble on for much longer about why I love this game, but I'll try to throw together a good old fashion pro's and cons list 

Pro's:
-Beautiful fantasy art style and graphics. Every unit in the game looks great right from the start, but as they level up and purchase new weapons and armor their appearance changes in a satisfying and meaningful way. A level 1 warrior looks like nothing compared to a level 15 warrior.

-Combat, while not being super involved on the part of the player, is always satsifying and fun to watch. As your units learn new skills either from training at a guild, or from leveling up, the way they fight changes. It's always neat to see the heroes fighting in new ways as the game goes on.

-Intimidating monsters and quests that will challenge you. Because of the unusual method for defending your kingdom, it's not nearly so easy to defend in this game. Bunkering up with thousands of troops is not something you can do, so proper management is something you'll have to learn

-Great silly voice acting from the royal advisor, and many good lines from your units. The dialog is just fun, that's all there really is to say about that.

-Economics are easy to grasp, not spreadsheet material, but not piss easy either. You will run out of money, and you will suffer for it, but you wont need a college degree to figure out how to maintain your kingdom.

Con's:

-The game is hard, and if you've never played a majesty game before, then you're going to have a bit of a rough time starting out (Though for some this can easily be a pro)

-It's frontloaded. Many missions are only hard at the start. By the time you establish your kingdom and have several powerful heroes wandering around, you'll easily take the rest of the mission by storm. (This is more of a problem with the vanilla campaign, and not so much with the DLC's)

-Takes forever to unlock everything. You will have to complete over 70% of the in game missions to have every building and unit unlocked. This can be frustrating if your favorite unit or building is one of the very last to be unlocked.
 
-AI is sometimes very stupid. Generally your units will do fine without your guidance and only need you to give them a quest for something majorly out of the way, like to raid an enemy keep, or defend a trading post. But sometimes a unit will choose to go to the store when a lich is about to blow their house to smithereens, and....well that is annoying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018659517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3098, 'last_played': 1586539471}
review:
The game offers a very unique and interesting gameplay experience. It is well crafted and stable and no bugs have come to my knowing. It has some minor balance issues and design flaws. Overall i can recommend this game to people interested in RTS, who like to take on a challenge. This game is difficult. Stay away from it if you can not stand losing over and over again.

The UI is thought out well and is very intuitive.
Visuals are done nicely, no eyesore to be expected.
The current standard price of about 20$ is more than justified.



What is it about?
To sum it up: The russian devs have built a hero management simulation on top of a classic RTS basis. It plays pretty fresh, and feels damn good.

Basically, the units you build have minds on their own. There is no way to directly control them.
They do hero stuff, they wander around in search of monsters and loot, they level up just like all heroes do and can become even better with shinier armor and bigger swords.
Given some time, success and little dying they can develop from a wooden sword swinging wannabe knight to a professional murdering machine.

They misjudge their chances and die in silly ways quite often, hindering the individual progress, cost you a lot of money and ultimately, cause you to fail the map. So, the chaotic bunch needs to be directed somehow. 
This is where the player jumps in. You can interact with various Spells on a smaller scale, but: What do heroes like ? Exactly, shiny things and money.

Orders are handled by issuing quests. For example, there is a wolves den which annoys you. You can create a quest for your guys, by putting a reward on it. Heroes will take on that quest if they feel like its worth it, and soon, the wolves den will be history.
The earned money then goes to that heroes purse and he will use it to buy Potions, enchant or buff himself in Guildhouses or buy new equipment if he doesn't die before he can spend it.
The money spent by heroes comes back to your purse for the most part, so its a game of give and take. With the added risk of the hero dying, resulting in loss of that money with additional resurrection costs. (These can become very very costly with increasing levels)

All Heroes will be acting selfishly on their own by default, giving little to no support to the "competing" heroes. Later on, you get the Option to group them into parties of up to four, making them work together to combine their abilities and increase in power by a lot. But also decreasing their response to quests significantly, which means, they'll consider themselves very elite and move out only for phat lewt.

After every mission you get the chance to promote one hero to "Lord", saving him for reuse on the following maps. Which is a good but costly option. Some maps can only be won by utilizing this feature wisely. All other heroes are lost on map transition.

This might sound all nice and cozy, and, yeah, when the basics are understood, the first few missions are not much of a problem.
But the difficulty rises quite fast and brutal. The maps are very different from each other and you will need to come up with a solid build order and make it work over several attemps on each new mission again. You are under constant attack from the very beginning and can fail the mission very fast if attempting the wrong way. Gamechanging scripted events can cause sudden death even later on if handled wrong. 

It soon becomes a game of Chess, were you will need a clear plan of what to do when and perfect execution. The combination of this with the games occasional randomness can cause frustration at times. You've done nothing wrong, but still are wiped out brutally.

This factor will multiply when later on, your opponents have leveling heroes as well, and failure will therefore be punished twice, by losing a lot of money, and having to face more powerful enemies. Resulting in very very frustrating moments.


I'd say, the game, a couple of hours in, is a lot about trial and error and aims towards players with some dedication and will to win and has nothing to offer for casual players at all.
For the more hardcore, there is a lot of fun to be had here.


Having played the first part too, i really hope for a Majesty 3, the Game has come a long way already. I hope the developers see that too and give it another attempt. They could turn this already damn good, but underdog, game into a total blockbuster.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156954345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1668742325}
review:
Incredibly disappointed in the development of this game. 

I loved the first few missions in the campaigns. It was reminiscent of the first game and I was LOVING it. Come to the Rat King and the mission with Rafnir- my campaign has come to a standstill. Within the first 45 seconds (not even enough time to get a guard tower built), your town is overrun by either rats or dragons (depending on which quest you are on). The provided guards are weak, slow, and have no actual endurance, and are killed quickly. If you ARE lucky enough to get a hero guild up (obviously warriors seem to get you the farthest) the level one warriors are greeted by level 3-5 mobs and are killed quickly, closely followed by the destruction of the guild, wasting the 500g you just spent. 

I've tried every imaginable offensive and defensive strategy, followed people's reccomendations, and to no avail, I still sit stuck on those two quests. 

What is the good of the overrun tactic? How is the game supposed to be enjoyable? The missions are basically the same, just different mobs and landscapes. Try not to get overrun, and try to afford heroes to go to some place and escort a caravan that will quickly become monster fodder because they're weak and the hero AI makes them a bunch of wimps. 

Sad, sad experience, 1C. Sad. You've suceeded in ruining what was hopeful to be a wonderful reawakening of one of my favorite games. Just glad I didn't pay full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993368900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1433019770}
review: Coming from many, many, MANY hours spent playing the original Majesty, this game really feels like a letdown.  Where in the original the characters and buildings were unique and instantly recognizable, the opposite is true here.  At first glance, the guilds all look the same.  The same is true for the heroes.  They also seem to have reused much of the audio from the original, which is not a positive in my mind.  This isn't because the original was bad in that respect, but it looks really lazy on their part.  Maybe I'll come back and really put some time into this game at some point and find it has a lot to offer, but probably not before putting in another 100+ with the original (and to my mind, better) Majesty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038955118', 'num_games_owned': 720, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 4198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4198, 'last_played': 1373024797}
review:
[h1]Скорость и мастерство ничего не значат, если нет надлежащего контроля.[/h1]
Вначале думал, что полная хрень, после нескольких часов игры, убедился, что это не так. Красивая графика, интересный сюжет. Здесь есть своя изюминка – Вы не управляете солдатами, не покупаете им броню и оружие, они все делают самы. Откуда у них берутся деньги!? Вот тут Вы им помогаете. Находите логово чудовищ или разбойников на карте и ставите там флажок и указываете сумму, которую получат солдаты после того как доберутся до этого места. Согласитесь, весьма своеобразный способ управления солдатами. Мне такая новизна понравилась. 
Также приятно порадовало, что данный шедевр выпустили на свет наши отечественные разработчики. Единственный минус – отсутствие в стиме русского языка у игры выпущенной российской компанией. Слава Богу, что есть русификатор. Всем любителям и поклонникам жанра «немецких экономических стратегий» данная игра понравится. 
Моя оценка 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022018964', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 19497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18025, 'last_played': 1585924717}
review:
Majesty 2 is a very fun game!

The single mission are very tough tough.
You build your little kingdom and train your hero's but from then the hero's are on their own. You create a market where they can purchase potions and a blacksmith where they can buy weapons and armor. By reward flags (that are off course not free) you can lurk your hero's to do your bidding while constantly being attacked by al kinds of real and mythical monsters who grow stronger and stronger. You like the monsters because they level up your hero's and give you income and you hate the monsters because they destroy lots of things. Death and destruction is everywhere.

If u like an entertaining game this is one for you!

ps one downside; the multiplayer sucks and this game will never be good at being a multiplayer game...

author: {'steamid': '76561198128403353', 'num_games_owned': 742, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1699090756}
review:
Conheci Majesty la por 2001, em um CD de demos da revista Estratégia(cd de demos, to ficando velho), foi amor instantaneo. Um jogo de RPG e estratégia que o jogador não controla nenhum personagem, somente administra a cidade e os heróis. Não tenho ideia de quantas vezes zerei o demo e o jogo completo de majesty 1. 10 anos depois que descobri majesty 1, eu descobri Majesty 2 e o encanto e personalidade não mudaram.
Eu recomendo todas as expansões(uma expansão em que o jogador tem um unico objetivo, combater goblins, tem algo melhor do que ver paladinos matando goblins? tem tambem uma outra expansão que o jogador controla os monstros( ratos, shamans, minotauros e etc)).
Majesty é garantia de horas de diversão, e raiva as vezes, pois os heróis nem sempre enfrentam os desafios e fogem por se acharem fracos perante o inimigo, ou não terem pots e afins. Mas isso é um ponto fraco? Pelo contrário, os hérois tendem a fugir de desafio muito perigosos, então o jogador pode formar parties pra deixar os heróis mais confiantes e assim cumprir os objetos necessários, assim como acontece em qualquer RPG.
Uma franquia que admiro a quase 15 anos, e acredito que vou admirar e me divertir por muito mais tempo ainda

author: {'steamid': '76561197988208226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6136, 'last_played': 1611125553}
review: Second iteration of one of my favorite games of all times... I still use the expressions of the characters of the heroes in the original Majesty and probably will forever. In many ways it is much like the first one, with the addition of the Hero party system (which is extremely helpful: you can party up your strongest characters and pwn). You also get artifacts that can be used in future missions, there's new flags, improved multiplayer, and of course much better in terms of it's engine, graphics, and physics. If you loved the first one (and got it with your old Gateway like I did) you'll play the hell out of this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063466136', 'num_games_owned': 46, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1425838848}
review:
Hey all.

I'm coming from Majesty 1.

Basically, to me, it's same game with a little bit advanced graphics.
New flag mechanics are satisfying (ie defend flag).

In Majesty 2 you overall have more controll on your units which is a good thing... but a bad thing.

You see, whole thing about majesty 1 was that you are a King. So you have wishes and a bunch of gold to make wishes come true and there are people who can help you to do that. If they want to. In Majesty 2 you cannot feel that atmosphere of being a king. It's more like an ordinary RTS game.

Besides, despite advanced graphics, I like original Majesty art better. I mean buildings, characters etc. They were more authentic than in Majesty 2. Here we have some genereic medieval buldings and not a Rogue's guild or Temple of Krypta.

When I'm playing the original Majesty, I always imagine myself as Vetinari, the patrician of Ankh-Morpork. Obviously the city, which I am building is Ankh-Morpork. Dunno, I always imagined Ankh-Morpork just like that.

I would like to have sequel, which have art and AI of original Majesty. Not a generic gimped RTS.

Nevertheless, if we look at this as a separate game and not a sequel, then it's pretty nice.

Conclusion is: if you want some new experience in strategy games definitely get this. If you're an old-school fan of Majesty, then I don't think that you will like this, because it's lacks the atmosphere of original game. It's better for you to view this as a stand-alone game.

review:
Awesome game! This game is simply great...
It's a mix with rts game and like mmo style (but not massive) with level progression, quests and so many others stuffs.
The difference with other rts is that you don't interact directly on units. You simply put some quests here and there and make offers. Then your kingdom acts!
This is strongly addicting! First time i played this game i stayed 11 hours non-stop without eating or something else! My hand was red because of hanging the mouse.

But there's still a lan mode, so I think you can still play it online with software like hamachi or maybe game ranger, i don't know...
Just go into it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997009554', 'num_games_owned': 971, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 13795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5792, 'last_played': 1636518167}
review:
Majesty 2 es un RTS combinado con RPG y simulación ambientado en el mundo de Ardania, un mundo de fantasía en el que habitan feroces enemigos y poderosas criaturas mágicas. Hombres rata, dragones, goblins, hechiceros, ogros y demás, tienen su lugar aquí. Nosotros como aspirantes a Rey de Ardania, deberemos enfrentar y derrotar a todos y cada uno de ellos, ya que representan una amenaza seria para nuestro reino y su gente.

Junto al Rey, está el siempre fiel Consejero Real, un asistente que nos dará, con cierto humor, la información que necesitamos para cada una de las misiones de las campañas principales. También nos ofrecerá consejos en momentos clave, y quizás alguna que otra divertida curiosidad adicional referida al mundo de Ardania o sus habitantes.

Hay que destacar que este juego combina perfectamente RTS, por la vista isométrica en 3D y la construcción/administración de una base (aquí llamada "reino"), el RPG, por la unidad básica (pero a su vez compleja) de ataque, exploración y defensa que usaremos: los héroes, y finalmente, la simulación, por la forma en que se repara y mantiene todo en orden automáticamente, como si fuera un "tycoon", incluyendo la evolución progresiva de nuestro reino, sus riquezas y sus respectivos héroes.

Los héroes son la espina dorsal del juego, pues sin ellos nuestro reino quedaría indefenso y no podríamos avanzar en las campañas. Existen diferentes clases: exploradores, guerreros, paladines, pícaros, clérigos, magos, sacerdotisas y, en uno de los DLCs, hasta incluso podremos usar goblins y poderosos hombres lobo. Todos los héroes tienen sus respectivas cofradías (o templos, en algunos casos) donde se albergan y entrenan un número limitado de éstos. Allí también pueden aprender nuevas habilidades, si uno puede pagar las mejoras edilicias correspondientes previamente, claro está.

Cada uno lleva un inventario propio, donde cargan las armas, armaduras, pociones, etc, y también tienen sus propias estadísticas, como fuerza o inteligencia. Al luchar, ganan experiencia que les permite subir niveles y obtener habilidades específicas de cada clase, por lo que se vuelven más poderosos y resistentes luego de cada combate. Su principal interés es ganar mucho oro, y pueden obtenerlo con cada baja o "quest" que les asignemos.

En este juego, no se pueden dar órdenes directas a ningún héroe o unidad en nuestro reino, ya que todos son autónomos, tienen sus propias necesidades o intereses particulares y deciden por sí mismos, por lo que son capaces de curarse solos, huir de un combate si se ven en desventaja o ignorarnos si quieren ir a descansar o a comprar algo. Para "controlarlos", uno sólo puede asignarles las llamadas "banderas" de ataque, exploración o defensa. Esto significa que si "marcamos" un objetivo con la bandera de ataque por ejemplo, primero debemos asignarle un monto en oro como recompensa por la tarea. Los héroes interesados irán a la misma, si lo desean o no, pero los que vayan, atacarán nuestro blanco hasta que muera o sea destruido y cobrarán su parte equitativamente. Mientras más alto sea el monto de oro ofrecido, más chances hay de convencer a cualquier héroe que haga lo que necesitamos.

Construir una herrería permite a nuestros héroes comprar mejores armas y armaduras. Un mercado nos da el acceso básico a pociones de salud, maná y algunos artefactos mágicos como los anillos o colgantes y, finalmente, el bazar mágico nos da las mejores pociones hechas para el ataque y/o la defensa. Los héroes beberán cada poción cuando sea necesario para curarse, restaurar maná o aumentar significativamente su rendimiento en combate.

Cada héroe que gane oro matando o cumpliendo nuestras quests, lo gastará en nuestras tiendas y dejará un pequeño porcentaje como tributo en sus cofradías, algo que constantemente recolectarán los recaudadores de impuestos, que representan la base fundamental de nuestra economía. También se puede ganar oro adicional cumpliendo algunas misiones, pero la mayoría se obtiene simplemente a través del tributo de nuestra gente. No existe ningún otro recurso que recolectar, por lo que hay que administrar bien lo que tenemos.

Si construimos una posada (un lugar donde nuestros héroes pueden descansar y comer algo) tendremos la posibilidad de armar manualmente un "party" (grupo). Estos grupos de cuatro héroes como máximo irán juntos a todos lados, se ayudarán entre ellos y compartirán las recompensas en oro. Aquí se pueden aplicar las tácticas más efectivas y usadas en otros RPGs o MMORPGs, tranquilamente: 1 tank (guerrero, paladín, etc.), 2 DPS rango o melé (arqueros, pícaros, etc.) y un healer (clérigo o sacerdotisa). También es útil añadir algún héroe de soporte con capacidad para CC (crowd control), como el mago, capaz de congelar, o el pícaro, capaz de aturdir, envenenar y debilitar.

Técnicamente, el juego se ve genial y tiene bastante colorido. Los gráficos son buenos para la época, aunque les hubiera venido bien más bumpmapping a las texturas. Las sombras se ven muy bien al igual que los hechizos y modelos en general. Es posible ver pequeños detalles como las armas y armaduras que van cambiando a medida que los héroes adquieren experiencia y consiguen nuevos ítems. Las animaciones son decentes y variadas, gracias a la captura de movimientos. Los edificios se despedazan de a poco y se desploman usando física realista, similar a otros juegos como Age of Empires III. Los sonidos son decentes, aunque la música es algo repetitiva (aún así es bastante buena). Las voces de algunos héroes son un poco flojas y no suenan bien. La mejor voz, sin dudas, es la de nuestro Consejero Real porque tiene un toque cómico único pero a su vez suena creíble y muy bien actuada.

Desgraciadamente, este juego tiene una buena cantidad de problemas aún sin resolver. Bugs visuales y sonoros, como la falta de voces en determinados momentos, posiblemente asociados a serios problemas de memoria, ya que el juego consume MUCHA memoria RAM, hasta el punto de crashear y ralentizar todo, por lo que es importante guardar la partida seguido. Para poder jugar con fluidez y todas las opciones gráficas activadas incluido antialiasing necesitas, por lo menos, el doble o triple de los requisitos mínimos especificados.

La IA, si bien es decente, también tiene sus defectos: los héroes no siempre huyen de los combates y a veces mueren de formas ridículas, incluso cuando son expertos. Tampoco suelen prestar atención a nuestras banderas a menos que paguemos un costo excesivamente alto en oro y, en algunos casos, hasta ignoran completamente el peligro que puede acechar, como un hombre lobo o dragón acercándose lentamente a nuestro reino. La forma en que buscan blancos automáticamente también es floja: tiene más prioridad una rata de alcantarilla que un ejército de goblins o un par de poderosos hombres lobo. Es posible que algunos héroes incluso no salgan a defender sus propias cofradías cuando están bajo ataque, porque prefieren irse de compras, o directamente entrar a descansar antes que defender su "hogar". Esto suele llevar a derrotas frustrantes en casos muy específicos, pero podrían ser totalmente evitables.

En definitiva, si te gustan los RTS con toques de RPG, éste es un juego único, MUY divertido y se puede considerar uno de los mejores de su tipo dentro de la industria. Te ofrecerá docenas de horas de diversión garantizadas, a pesar de sus defectos. Muy recomendado.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980923585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 3690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3771, 'last_played': 1481519912}
review:
Há um bom tempo possuo Majesty 2 e por alguma razão o deixei de lado na minha biblioteca.
Nesta semana, olhando os jogos que possuo, o vi e abri para brincar um pouco, e como isso me deixou contente, pois Majesty 2 é realmente divertido e desafiante!

Neste RTS você não controla as unidades, que são heróis das classes, em inglês, Warrior, Rogue, Ranger, Priest e Mage. Você cria missões, "quests" para que os heróis, se quiserem, cumpram. E quanto maior o nível deles, mais você precisa desembolsar, haha.
Você, o Rei, ganha Ouro com o mercado, onde os heróis compram poções, ou com a ferraria, onde eles se equipam. Então você precisa, literalmente, gastar dinheiro para fazer dinheiro.

Os heróis se equipam sozinhos, evoluem, adquirem novas habilidades, e no caso de não haver nenhuma missão no mapa, tomam suas próprias decisões. Na taverna você pode montar grupos (a famosa "party"), que enfrentam desafios maiores com mais facilidade.

Você, o Rei, decide quantos acampamentos de cada classe quer ter. Cada acampamento serve a 3 indivíduos da classe específica. É possível ainda, num nível avançado, evoluir os heróis para classes como Assassin, Blademaster, Paladin, etc, que são muito mais fortes e determinadas.
Numa certa missão, após todos os meus heróis morrerem, um único paladino nível 18 conseguiu matar o mestre e salvar minha campanha de 50 minutos, hahaha. Nossa, como vibrei naquele momento.

E ainda tem multiplayer!

Enfim, Majesty 2 vale muito a pena para qualquer amante de RPG e RTS, e isso sem contar as pitadas de humor que torna tudo mais divertido!

Recomendo com certeza!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076665762', 'num_games_owned': 1337, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 1560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1560, 'last_played': 1410980507}
review:
[h1]Strategy meets RPG[/h1]

A very nice blend of [b]RTS, RPG and economic game[/b]. You are the ruler of Ardania, Fantasy Kingdom. You construct the guilds, economic buildings, research better weapons and shields. But you cannot control your heroes directly. They are controlled by setting rewards for specific goals like exploring a territory or killing a monster.

There is a variety of missions and quests, some of which require attacking specific places or killing a monster which requires certain strategy. Others require simultaneous construction of some temples or defending a merchant caravan.

"Majesty 2" has nice, [b]colorful 3D fantasy graphics[/b] and music which sets the mood really nice (with some beautifully epic pieces for final monster fights). There is a huge choice of [b]hero classes[/b] like [b]warriors, wizards, rogues, clerics, paladins[/b] and nice selection of monsters with their dwellings including vampire crypts, elemental portals and wolf dens.

The game has a unique style merging some qualities of "Heroes of Might and Magic", some of "Age of Empires" and others from RPG games. Many missions are really demanding. I needed to consult strategy guides to finish some of the levels, but even after reading a strategy guide you can find your unique tactics to defeating the boss. After 25 hours of playing I have finished this [u]really enjoyable game[/u].

author: {'steamid': '76561198071520127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1200, 'last_played': 1503531188}
review:
Moc dobrá hra. Pro spousta hráčů může být na počátku náročná. Není zde nastavení obtižnosti, mise jsou prostě postupně těžší. Může to znamenat zásek, zároveň to je ale i výzva. Některé mise jsou velmi těžké, hlavně na počátku, ale zatím jsme všechny zvládnul. 

Koncept hry, kdy nejde ovládat jednotlivé hrdiny, ale hrdinové se do jisté míry ovládají sami, je příjemný. Je krásné sledovat, jak si nakupují nové věci, pobíhají po mapě, bojují, získávají zkušenosti. Je potřeba mít trpělivost, než hráč příjde na některé herní mechanismy (jako všechny nové hrdiny v pozdějších fázích hry dávat okamžitě do skupin s klerikem, aby zbytečně neumírali, atd.). Trochu zamrzí, že koncept hry je pořád stejný. Chybí trochu větší propojení s hrdiny, postupné dostávaní nových budov. Moc chybí nekonečné hraní (někdy by hráč rád po dokončení hry prostě nechal na sebe posílat vlny nepřátel a dostavěl tu budovu a vynalezl ještě tamto brnění..) a custom game. 

Přes obtížnost a některé nedostatky přesto moc příjemná a odpočinková hra, kterou jde hrát hodiny bez snahy vyhrát misi a ukončit jí, ale pouze pro prosté potěšení z hemžicího se a funkčního království.

review:
So I played the original Majesty as a kid. I never knew there was a squeal until about a two weeks ago. Of course I had to buy it. 

Overall, it's a decent game. My only complaints come from being so in love with the original. The AI seems a little iffy. Your heros don't act anything like they did in the original. In my opinion, it is a lot harder to get them to venture aware from your starting area. Also - in the original you were able to follow your heros around very very easily. In this version it is a lot more disjointed.

Overall, I would say that the original is better. But if you are really interested - $20 isn't a bad price and you will probably get your moneys worth in the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021846766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1861, 'last_played': 1421184837}
review:
Alright, here is my review after putting in half a day's worth of time in to this game. Oh, and before I go any further, no, I did not complete the campaign, I'll get to why in a moment. So, without further delay, here is my breakdown of this game.

First of all, this game is for masochists, whether you got an unnoficial "balancing mod" or not. This is hands down the most frustrating misuse of a fantastic idea I've ever seen. The idea is pretty great, a fantasy sim city builder that tasks you with managing the kingdom by building and providing incentives for things to get done, all while your heroes do their "best" to rise in level and maybe usefullness. There's also some great voicing, at least on your side, and some pretty cool ideas that actually pan out (such as creating parties), but that's about it. 

Now, for the long list of absolutely terrible crap that will continue to make your gaming experience hell. To start with, difficulty, there isn't any way to control this as the game goes from novice to advanced after two missions (read easy to holy hell wtf happened to my town?!) A lot of your completed missions thereafter are based off of luck rather than skill due to enemy spawns and constant zerg-like-rushing. Oh, did I forget to mention that? Yeah, there is absolutely zero room whatsoever for flexible strategy. Thanks to that weird developer minset you'll find that some heroes are just plain worthless, causing you to only waste your gold on their buildings for upgrades. Oh, speaking of gold, enemies don't rely on any kind of resource for whatever unholy reason, and can continue to pump wave after wave at you until you take care of their spawns. This is usually only mildly irratible however, on some later missions, you'll find yourself constantly under pressure or on the brink of ruin merely two or so minutes into a level. So if you like rushing your missions by pumping out the right heroes from the get go without actually taking the time to enjoy the game (read play for more than five minutes per mission) then this is the game for you. If you like to take your time to actually enjoy your purchase, forget this game, seriously just forget it.

So, if you've actually made it this far in my review and still wish to purchase this game AND don't consider yourself a masochist, I strongly recommend you dowload an unoffical balance mod. The one I used came from this site: "https://esatire.wordpress.com/2012/07/09/majesty-2-is-actually-fun-now-thanks-to-modding/" and it helped me somehow manage to enjoy myself up until a particularly frustrating mission called "Royal Feat". Honestly if game developers design it so that you have to play a fantasy/sim builder/RTS as a juiced up version of Starcraft from zerg-rush hell then they're doing something incredibly, moronically, wrong.

I get way less stress playing the Ikko Ikki on Total War: Shogun 2. And it's far more enjoyable....

review:
The gameplay of Majesty 2 is much like the original, with just a bit more control and alot more humor. You still cannot directly control your heroes, but they appear much more responsive to reward flags. 
The game feels more challenging with higher level, more difficult monsters appearing sooner and more frequently. Objectives are also not always the clearest after each campaign briefing, but by the time you get your kingdom running you will get the gist.

Plays and feels quite a bit like the first Majesty game, and so was exactly what I was looking for. It is an enjoyable, fairly simple mechanics kingdom sim. Not neccessarily a 'serious' game, just something to have some fun with.

review:
At the moment of writing this I'm on the last mission of the first pack. That's about 30 hours in. Though challenging, with many reloads, I still think that this game is worth the effort. 

It's not your typical RTS/Sim for reasons you've probably read in other reviews. You are literally on 'the outside', a meagre - yet godly - influence on events which occur in your high fantasy domain, controlling heroes and building  constructions from the clouds above. 

But rest assured your choices either make it or break it!

A truly unique game which I will enjoy for many hours yet. I only wish I discovered this series sooner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047135033', 'num_games_owned': 2359, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 2098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1422324867}
review:
Minha análise é baseada na minha experiência em Majesty 2, não joguei o 1º jogo da série...
Apostei no game porque sou fã de RTS, achei interessante a proposta de uma gestão indireta e fui brindado por uma inovadora forma de se jogar, o game me supreendeu, realmente os personagens tem vida própria, alguns inteligente, outros corajosos mas suícidas e alguns vagabundos mesmo. Com uma pitada de RPG, eles acmulam experiência e também compram melhorias, sim porque para eles fazerem o que você quer, eles precisam de incentivo financeiro, No final de cada fase você pode salvar um hérois para continuar jogando com ele em outras fases, apesar que fortes hérois têm custo de convocação muito alto, tornando a possibilidade de utilizar pequena.
O jogo têm um problema de fechar sem motivo, bem no meio da jogatina, o que cria a necessidade de ficar salvando o jogo de tempos em tempos.
Um fator que irrita é a IA dos personagens, um rogue nivel 1 corre para a morte contra um tropa de zumbis enquanto um maldito elfo nivel 30 fica "procurando aventuras" sem sair de perto de sua base, um saco isso.
Em suma, indico para aqueles que querem um RTS diferente, o gráfico não é do melhores mas compensa com as novidades da mecânica de um game que merecia um melhor polimento em sua IA.
Publicada em: 12 de dezembro.	 Última edição: 12 de dezembro.

review:
Hopelessly broken thanks to an insistence on requiring access to a service that no longer exists and the coupling of enemy growth and events to hardware specs that are no longer current.  Although potential work-arounds exist and fan-made patches have attempted to rectify the game being unplayable, most are no longer supported by their respective programmers or work as intended thanks to official "updates" that don't fix the game themselves but do break methods used to fix it by well-meaning fans.  As it stands, these don't appear to work at all for many players; most didn't for me.  This leads to inactive DLC, broken questlines, borderline impossible difficulty, non-functional units, or all of the above.

The developer appears to have completely abandoned this version of the game and now sells what I can only assume is a version that actually works for full price.  For obvious reasons I choose not to re-buy a game I already bought in the hope that it will actually work, and the fact that the publisher has chosen to break the game, leave it unplayable, and then ask for an additional payment to have an identical game that MIGHT function in place of the product they already sold once is the worst kind of anti-consumer nonsense.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976285399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 19037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7751, 'last_played': 1707179239}
review:
Majesty 2 (and the expansion packs) build upon the experience of the first one, that is, a strategy game where you cannot control any of your units. Instead you supply them with potions, new weapons, enchantsments etc. In order for them to do your dirty jobs, you'll have to place bounty flags on targets (whether it's for killing or defending). 

Now, for the actual review; I found myself drawn into this game rather fast - I was a big sucker for the first one, and even though this one gave off a different 'vibe', I did end up falling in love. It wasn't this "love-at-first-sight" dealy like with Majesty 1, but rather a more of a rebound type of love. You know the feeling. She looks like your ex, she talks like your ex, even somewhat similar personalities -- but at the end of the day it's NOT your ex. 
For all intends and purposes this *is* Majesty - but without the British accent - without the extra edge and charm. 
The Campaign was interesting, and I'm fond of the fact that they mention the acheivements of the previous rulers (you). The Expansions were... Meh. I mean new missions - yay - doesn't help that they are rather bland. Don't even get me started on the Monsters-pack, so many spelling errors etc. 

What I'm trying to say is... Don't fool yourself into thinking this is Majesty. It isn't. It plays the same way, and it's great as a standalone title. Just don't be blinded by the title and the shiny "2" after it.

For this kind of game it's quite nice. 7/10.

review:
This gets too difficult very quickly and there is no way to lower the difficulty.
The first few levels were fun.

I am a casual gamer that do not want to spend hours doing the same mission over and over and over.

I like the fact that you have to give your units incentives to get anything done. You can not command them directly. It is something different.

There is a lot to like about the game, but the fact that you can not lower the difficulty level is a show stopper for me.

To quote the elves when they get killed in the game: "This is no fun - at all"

Edit 2015-06-01
I got the following advice from a user called "Patient Zero" and it made the game a bit more playable (I could get past the "King Rat" mission. It was still difficult, but at least it was doable):

Try this
https://esatire.wordpress.com/2012/07/09/majesty-2-is-actually-fun-now-thanks-to-modding/

I still do not recommend it without the mod.

review:
Отличная игра, сюжет хорош, игра состоит в том чтобы ваше королевство процветало, для этого надо защитить его строениями и нанимать героев, суть таже как и в любой стратегии, но здесь нет возможности командовать данным юнитом (героем) которого вы наймёте они сами себе хозяева и сами иследуют всю окрестность, а руководить можно ими лишь вознаграждениями которые вы можете поставить за данную задачу: типо разрушить здание, иследовать местность и охранять данное здание или человека.
Игра очень интересна и забавна и не похожа на обычную стратегию, этим она и особенна, всем советую.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198070846161', 'num_games_owned': 1724, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1414276970}
review:
Weshalb machen alle Strategiespiele das? Die Umgebung zu deinem Feind machen, das ist so unangenehm und macht überhaupt keinen Spass. Wenn es in einem Spiel darum geht, dann kann ich es vermeiden, aber wenn das Spiel sich selber als Aufbaustrategiespiel verkauft hoffe und wünsche ich mir jedesmal ein gutes Aufbaustrategiespiel und nicht ein "beende die Missionen so schnell wie möglich, oder du wirst von den Umgebungsmonstern überrant"-Spiel. 
Das Spiel hatte gute Ansätze mit diesem ganzen Fahnensystem, auch wenn ich wirklich ärgerlich fand, dass es so schwer war meine Krieger dazu zu überreden unaufgedecktes Gebiet zu erkunden. Aber sie machen einfach alles damit kaputt, dass sie Horden von Monstern, die man nicht besiegen kann und die über Zeit immer mehr und stärker werden und die ganze Zeit angreiffen, zufällig auf der Karte verteilen, in einem AUFBAUstrategiespiel muss man aufbauen können, das heisst das Spiel muss einem auch mal Zeit geben wo nicht dauernd gekämpft wird.
Ein Tipp den ich jedem neueren Strategiespiel geben kann, das ich gespielt habe ist, schaut euch Siedler 3 mal an, das Spiel war Spass pur zum Spielen und ich warte immer noch darauf, dass ein Strategiespiel herauskommt das auch nur annähernd so gut ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019447021', 'num_games_owned': 1791, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1491532476}
review:
This was the game I was looking for.  I discovered Majesty as a mobile app, and when I read that it was a port from PC (a well-done port, in my opinion), I decided to get it here on Steam.  I also got Majesty and Majesty HD, and while fundamentally similar in gameplay, they don't have the polished graphics that Majesty 2 has, and have that feel of a game a bit too old to get into in 2014.  If only I had played it a decade ago and had nostalgia driving me to return.

So in short, if you're looking for something different in RTS, namely a game where you don't directly control the heroes you've created, this is well worth some play time.  You build buildings and train adventurers of various classes.  You choose upgrades to stock the stores you've erected.  The adventurers you train will go out and explore and kill stuff, then buy items from the stores, provided you've researched the items they can afford.  When you want something killed or an area explored, you set a bounty and the adventurers decide who goes to collect.  The graphics aren't going to blow you away, but they're well-drawn and the game mechanics are a lot of fun.

One thing I've struggled with a bit: I haven't found any selectable difficulty options, and the levels are all laid out linearly despite being displayed on a map as though you could just select what challenge you're ready for.  When you progress to a difficult level, it is difficult and there isn't a lot you can do about it but retry until you figure out what you need to upgrade in what order.  This makes for a bit of tedium as you play for ten minutes and figure out that you lost in the first minute.  The only thing you can take with you between levels are heroes you've promoted to 'Lord' status, and if you've got some lords who are of a decent level but not too good you might be able to get a jump on a tough level, assuming you have enough starting gold to pay for the Hall of Lords and also to hire the lords, (the better they are, the more they cost, which limits the number of times you can do this as they will inevitably level up and cost more the next time you need them).  Outside of that, most levels require you to figure out the exact order to upgrade the exact right type of troops for each map, which removes any illusion of free will in how you approach each level, and a bit of the fun.

Bottom line: very challenging, bit more linear than I was hoping for, but a solid RTS-with-a-twist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082116541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1578009091}
review: Majesty has been my favorite RTS ever since playing it as a young kid on Windows 98 and the sequel has improved on a lot the first one had to offer. Majesty isn't your regular RTS, you don't actually control your units, you build your kingdom and then use your wealth to bribe your heroes and play into their personalities to get them into doing what you desire. This also isn't an easy game, it doesn't ♥♥♥♥ around you WILL have to restart some missions until you can develop a strategy, also I reccomend to play with the Randomize option on, otherwise when you restart you will just know where everything is. This collection comes with The base game and 3 expansions, I haven't even touched the expansions yet and already feel as though I got my moneys worth. Highly reccomended to anyone who likes RTS games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039929207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 788, 'last_played': 1707366420}
review:
Seeing so many negative reviews its a shame I can't add my review to Majesty 2 since I own the Collection edition. So here will suffice. I rate this game 8.5/10 and I played the original Majesty too (rate:9/10). M2 is a sim  RTS+RPG game, Like RTS games you have create an economy, research, create armies and destroy the opponents. The sim part is because you don't control the units (caled heroes). You assign rewards to kill a monster or destroy a building and depending on the reward 0 or more of your heroes will go achieve your task (more money = more heroes). There are soe 5 different kinds of tasks you can assign to heroes. The heroes will buy themselves upgrades provided that you created the necessary buildings and invested  on the research (which cost gold). Placing the buildings is your task and its important. There are defense towers and many other kinds of buildings (15+). Heroes level as they gain more experience (RPG component). I love this whole concept of the Majesty series. 

Plus points:

- Unique take on RTS
- A variety of heroes: gnomes, archers, paladins, monks, necromancers (some 15+ types)
- Rock-paper-scissors system. .
- Varied gameplay in the campaign. 
- RPG element s great. You can check each of your heroes and see what spells/powers they have learned.
- Game is well polished.

Minus points:

- Some of the latter missions are way too difficult. Basically, large number of monsters are thrown on your base before you even got the chance to set your economy. This frustrates the last 1/3 of the campaign. The first 2/3 are great. Its a shame. Maybe they should have add difficulty levels.
- So there are cheats and the player is forced to either spend hours figuring out how to beat each of these later missions or use the cheats, which is a shame either way.
- The concept is so amazing, one can't help feel that they could have designed a better campaign. One of the (hard) missions is to defeat two opposing kingdoms. It is incredibly cool as each of the opponents is using different armies. They could have thought other missions like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063941400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1514038244}
review:
Множество юнитов, которые ведут себя как ОНИ хотят, а не как вы пожелаете, хотя воздействие немного есть. Кучи монстров, которые хотят уничтожить вашу крепость. Редчайшие артефакты, которые вы получите в течении миссий. Приятная графика, музыка, всё это даже как-то успокаивает. Сюжет тоже можно назвать неплохим, он довольно стандартен для жанра фэнтези. От этой игры в самом начале будет трудно оторваться. Что же можно сказать о DLC? Например то, что они ничуть не хуже оригинальной игры, даже в чём-то лучше. В одном из дополнений мы получим возможность играть за гоблинов, уничтожая королевства. А в другом всё с точностью наоборот - будем уничтожать орды гоблинов. Все эти дополнения прибавят приличное количество часов к прохождению, что не может не радовать. Огорчает разве что отсутствие русского языка в стим-версии, но это уже мелочи. Вперёд, к трону Ардании!

9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061787954', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1315, 'last_played': 1580919688}
review:
Берите - не пожалеете, желательно вместе с оригиналом. Хороший сплав RPG/RTS, один из немногих шедевров непрямого контроля. Когда рядом с вашим замком прогуливается шайка гоблинов, терроризируя крестьянские дома, а ближайший свободный "великий маг" предпочитает вместо их аннигиляции сидеть в таверне или делать покупки на рынке - ну где еще такое найдёшь ? Ваши поданные точно знают, что спасибо на хлеб не намажешь.
Любителям первой части скажу вот что: дух оригинала на месте, некоторые вещи стали более логичными, казино и синие крыши эльфийских зданий, к сожалению, были заменены на типичную фэнтезюшную безвкусицу. Лично для меня главная потеря - визуальный стиль. Нет загрузочных артов, а портреты персонажей явно родом из 3D, разбойники сменили пол, а Крипта больше не привносит восточную стилистику. В общем новый стиль мне не импонирует так, как прежний. Но это, как ни странно, не мешает воспринимать игру как сиквел оригинала.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107504571', 'num_games_owned': 316, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1412606297}
review:
这款游戏的操作性可以说在即时战略游戏里算是独树一帜的。
你可以简单把这个游戏的背景当成魔兽的奇幻故事，但是它不是war3不需要你微操。
这游戏玩家玩起来更像是一名城市规划者，譬如暴风城的国王，嗯确实是的。
你不是魔兽争霸里面的统帅，更不是魔兽世界里的一个footman。这个游戏里footman都是给你打工的。
没有繁琐的建筑前缀，甚至连农民的房子都是他们自己建的。你需要做的是建立footman的行会，这样就可以招募他们。
雇佣的footman们会自己行动，战士、盗贼、猎人、法师和僧侣。平时保护城市，偶尔也会四处游动。
他们会打怪刷钱，而你的任务则是规划出供给他们消费的市场、组队用的酒馆和购买装备的铁匠铺。
至于大方向的行动则由几个简单的命令任务来完成：攻击、防守还是探索地图，赏金越高的任务越容易吸引他们去做，过强的怪物他们发现打不过则会逃命。
你可以建造各种祭坛选择把他们晋升成什么职介，总之玩这个有种站在上帝视角看别人玩魔兽世界剧情任务的一样，而我则创造各种任务来吸引勇者达成胜利。
作为一个单机游戏，推荐打折再入，这游戏打发时间还是很不错的！

author: {'steamid': '76561197971548533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 4057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2514, 'last_played': 1505814963}
review:
Voilà un petit jeu au concept asser étrange,

c'est un peu un mélange de "Age of Empire", de RPG, et d'un concepte qu'on ne vois pas souvent et dont on n'a aucun contrôle,

dans le jeu, nous n'avons aucun controle sur les gens, les héros ou autres personnes, nous somme le roi et nous ne faison que placer les bâtiments et offrir des primes pour incité les gens à faire quelque chose comme aller explorer un secteur particulier, ou si on désire voir une cachette de monstre détruite rapidement ou pour défendre un secteur...

L'IA ce débrouille asser bien seul, c'est asser comique de les regardé accomplir leur vie, puisqu'il sont completement indépendant de nous, et tout les personnage on leur propre inventaire et équipement, bien sur, on ne peut pas leur en donner, car comme il sont indépendant, c'est a eux qui décide ce qu'il veulent, nous, nous ne faison que construire des magasin et si quelque chose leur plaît alors il iron en acheter, si il ont l'argent...

pour ce qui est de l'argent, notre seul revenu sont les les impots, et pour les héros, si il veulent de l'argent il doivent la gagné en effectuant différente tâche comme tuer des monstre ou alors effectué une mission que vous offrer,

le système de mission est bien pensée, et pas compliqué, vous planté un drapeau sur un site de monstre par example et vous dites que vous offrer 100 pièces d'or ou plus à celui ou ceux qui détruiront ce site, et les personne intéressé irons essayé d'accomplir la tâche, mais c'est à eux de choisir si il y vont ou pas, et si la prime est très élevé, vous pourrez voir plusieur AI travailler ensemble pour essayé d'accomplir la dite tâche...

le jeu en temps que tel est répétitif de mission en mission, vous construisé des bâtiment et créer des héros et vous les regardé aller, mais c'est asser plaisant de voir les personnage ce déplaçé, certain préfère resté près des bâtiment et défendre la place, d'autre sont toujours partie en mission et certain autre sont de vraie poule mouillé qui ce sauvent au premier danger,

dans les option de jeu on peu activé les émoticon, icon qui permette de voir ce qu'il ressente, comme quand il décide de s'enfuir parcequ'il y à trop d'ennemi qui approche, ect...

il y a quelque voix asser commique mais sans plus, mais le jeu en totalement en français,

le jeu viens avec trois DLC et il y a un diteur de carte pour créer ces propres scénario, les graphiques sont très bien pour ce jeu et j'ai testé le jeu avec tout les option au maximum et je n'ai auncun problèmes, mais il est vraie que je joue lentement car trop de choses à gérer en même temps pour mon petit cerveau ha ha ha

il y a plusieur types de monstre et de héros, et il ont tous leur point fort et leur faiblesse, mais un des problèmes que les gens semble rencontré dès le début du jeu, c'est qu'il ce font tous démolir en partant, car même au début du jeu les monstre arrive de partout, il faut donc installer ses défenses le plus vite possible, sinon sa deviendra presque impossible, avoir trois ou quatre tour de défense et une tente pour créer un type de héros est une bonne idée en partant, quel type de tente de héros mettre, ça dépend des monstre, si vous commencer près d'entre de squelette, une église est une bonne idée car il sont les meilleur contre les squelette et en plus il peuvent guerrir les autres...

bref c'est un bon petit jeu que j'ai acheté en spécial a 75% et je ne le regrette pas, avec toute les mission et scénario qu'il offre, je crois que je vais en avoir pour un bout avant de passer à travers,

juste le fait de pouvoir regardé l'IA faire son travail est plaisant, voir comment les gens sont avar de ces primes que vous offrer pour tel ou tel mission et de les regardé aller dépenser leur argent durement gagné,

il y a des base de monstre impossible à détruire, comme les égout, et sur ce, c'est une bonne chose que certain héros préfère rester près de la ville, car des rats, il y en n'a beaucoup

ah! oui, au sujet du nombre de héros, durant mon test je n'ai pas vu de limites, il y a une limite de trois par bâtiment, mais il n'y a pas de limites de bâtiment donc vous pourrer en avoir 3 par bâtiment, mais attention, car si il n'y a pas de limite de bâtiment, plus vous en construiser, plus le prix devient élevé, même chose pour les tour de défense, et il est impossible de détruire les bâtimemnt une fois construit, il faut attendre qu'il ce fasse démolir, alors vaut mieux réfléchir avant d'installer un bâtiment...

quoi qu'il en soit, je recommende ce jeu, asser plaisant et j'ai bien hâte de voir la réaction de mes héros devant certain monstre,

les héros monte de niveau et obtienne de nouveau pouvoir ou option de combat et c'est très plaisant de voir les plus fort aller protéger les plus faibles, une fois la mission terminé on peut nommé un héros en noble que l'on pourra faire revenir dans la carte suivante, si on n'a l'argent, donc si vous avez accomplis cinq mission et nommé cinq noble, vous pourrer faire venir ces 5 noble en renfort dans votre nouvelle carte, et il garde tout leur inventaire et leur niveaus qu'il ont acquis, et si par malheur un de nos héros meurs, il seras possible de le ramené à la vie contre une somme d'argent, donc y'aura pas trop de deception ha ha ha

Pour les amateur de RPG, vous retrouverer beaucoup de créature mitique, comme le minotaure, les dragon, les squelettes, les loup-garou et les our-garou, ect..., préparer vous à perdre beaucoup de monde et a devoir les réssucité, car les monstre vous réserve beaucoup de surprise,

il est bon de changer de tactique si rien ne fonctionne dans une carte, il m'est arrivé de devoir recomencer une carte plus de dix ou 15 fois avant de pouvoir survivre..., donc armée vous de patience si vous devez recommencer, mais le jeu est très bien fait, c'est très plaisant de voir tout les effets ou de voir les héros se rassemblé pour tuer un monstre légendaire...

author: {'steamid': '76561198046480216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1412425459}
review:
A unique mix of Warcraft-ish ( or the much-forgotten Warlords style ) RTS and a simulation game. You can give instructions to your peasants to create buildings . You can hire heroes and upgrades from buildings ( AoE like system ).  However, you cannot control the heroes directly . They are like simulated RPG players  going on quests ( if the reward seems interesting enough ) , and gaining experience and levels as they defeat enemies.

Not interest in playing this in multi-player mode ( I doubt if anyone is playing this anymore ) , but the campaign is a lot of fun, and does require quite a few map resets , and loading at critical saves. Good ol' style strategy fun . 

Got the base game in one of the humblebundles , and upgraded to the collection coz I enjoyed the campaign a lot . Holds enough replayability if you start randomizing maps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015389315', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1595648837}
review:
A small scale empire builder where you have no direct control over your units. The closest you get are bounties you can set to have them attack enemies/buildings, defend buildings/caravans, explore an area, or stay away from something they are in no way ready to handle. As the king, you decide what gets built, what heroes get hired, things to research and upgrade, and are allowed to spend some of your cash on spells for more influence on the course of the game. 

Unfortunately, just like the first game, this one suffers from the problem of needing to be lucky for the first few minutes and hope that the den of mini-dragons that can kill every hero in one attack doesn't decide to send a wave towards you before you've even built a single barrack or guard tower. But the times when you don't get imediately fucked from the start are what make the game great. Do you invest in upgrading the rouges guild so that all your heroes have their weapons poisoned? Maybe build a guard tower next to the sewer entrance so that the ratmen that come from it don't ravage your marketplace? Or do you research better spells, equipment, and potions for your heroes to use? Coming to forkroads like that  and then playing them out to see if you made the right choice are what gives the game so much character, if you can bear the 10 failed attempts beforehand where a boss teir dragon decided to attack your palace as soon as you loaded the level.

review: Majesty has been my favorite RTS ever since playing it as a young kid on Windows 98 and the sequel has improved on a lot the first one had to offer. Majesty isn't your regular RTS, you don't actually control your units, you build your kingdom and then use your wealth to bribe your heroes and play into their personalities to get them into doing what you desire. This also isn't an easy game, it doesn't fuck around you WILL have to restart some missions until you can develop a strategy, also I reccomend to play with the Randomize option on, otherwise when you restart you will just know where everything is. This collection comes with The base game and 3 expansions, I haven't even touched  the expansions yet and already feel as though I got my moneys worth. Highly reccomended to anyone who likes RTS games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002686126', 'num_games_owned': 2416, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1629, 'last_played': 1404327736}
review:
Zuerst mal die Zusammenfassung: Der 1. Teil war ein wunderschönes Spiel, aber das hier ist das Worst Case Szenario was sie daraus machen konnten, der BER der Softwaretechnik... Also mal los:

Grafik/Sound: Fange ich mit dem guten an. Auch wenn das Spiel schon etwas auf dem Buckel hat, die Schicken Texturen und guten Modelle sehen sogar gut aus. Vorausgesetzt man hat Zeit sich das anzusehen...

Steuerung: Ist ganz Okay. Die wenigen Keybindings die es gibt (oder die fehlende Ausschilderung)  führen dazu dass man ohne ende rumklickt, es bleibt aber von dieser Seite recht spielbar, allerdings bräuchte man hier Keybindings um das Gesammtpacket gut spielen zu können.

Strategy Design: Totales Fiasko! Dieses Spiel ist so schlecht gebaut, dass es einfach nicht geht. Theoretisch ein schönes Spiel aber man kommt nicht zum spielen, aufgrund dessen dass du eh Pausenlos von ner anderen Seite angegriffen wirst und eventuelle Bossgegner dir ohne Punkt und Komma bei jedem Auftauchen die halbe Basis zerlegen und wieder abdampfen (Beginnend meist ca 30 Sek nach Levelbeginn). Dieses Spiel ist durch die Art und weise des Level und Gegnerdesigns absolut unspielbar und nur was für Leute die auf Hardcore Strategie stehen oder sich Pausenlos ärgern wollen. 

Fazit: Bloß nicht kaufen, total unspielbar. Wen es interessiert empfehle ich den alten 1. Teil, aber dieses Spiel ist das schlimmste vom schlimmsten.

review:
One of the rare few indirect control strategy games out there, and subsequently one of the best.
While AI is somewhat lacklustre, the game mechanics are quite addictive and you can find yourself playing a single scenario for two or three hours until you drain the map completely.
A very enjoyable game that makes you feel in control, but not quite like a god. A very fresh experience compared to all the modern strategy and simulation games. This delivers a brilliant mix of both with a perfect blend of control or lack of it.
Much recommended for anyone who enjoys city building with a bit of action mixed in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964247971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 16559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8356, 'last_played': 1603571658}
review:
Inzwischen ist das Spiel schon etwas älter aber immer noch geniales Prinzip. Ich kenne auch kein anders Spiel das jemals auf diese Weise funktioniert.
Es ist praktisch ein MMORPG aus der Sicht des Königs, der seid Ihr.. Ihr heuert Helden an die selbständig Monster bekämpfen um an deren Gold zu kommen. Diese muessen Euch Steuern und Abgaben entrichten, dafür baut Ihr neue Gebäude, könnt verbesserte Waffen, Tränke, etc. erforschen die wiederum die Helden gegen Geld kaufen können. Als König könnt Ihr auch besondere Belohnungen in Form von Geld auf bestimmte Monster / Dungeons setzten. Dadurch greifen Eure Helden bevorzugt diese Ziele an.  Jeden Helden könnt ihr bis ins Detail anschauen, seine Stats wie Stärke, Ausdauer etc. Das ist zwar für Euch nicht so wichtig aber es gibt dem Spiel dieses geniale Spielgefühl. Alles ist bis ins Detail liebevoll ausgearbeitet. Ihr kämpft auch selten gegen X-beliebige Gegner sondern immer etwas besonderes wie die Hauptquests in MMORPGs. Mal muss man den übermächtigen Lichkönig bekämpfen, mal gegen Drachen, mal ist die blosse Anzahl der kleinen Gegner so hoch, dass Ihr verzweifelt.  Super Grafik, sämltiche Helden haben natürlich spezielle Skills, mit super Effekten.

Ich kann nur sagen kaufen kaufen kaufen. 

Von den DLCs ist lediglich der letzte "Monster Kingdom" richtig gut. Hier Spielt ihr aus der Sicht der Monster gegen die Menschen. Wer wollte nicht schon immer mal einen Werewolf in seiner Armee ? Genial.

review:
It's Majesty, what's not to like about it? A little easier than the 1st one and the world looks like Sacred 2 which I happen to have enjoyed, so yes, I say you should get this game. Only bug I found so far was not being able to set an attack flag on the goal castle but I built warrior and ranger guilds next to it and got a hero to lev 20 spam healing him while it "bugged" out. Not really a whole lot out there for newer fantasy RTS so may as well play it in my humble opinion.

EDITED - 1 thing tho missing is the ability to turn off the non stop Connery spam, it gets annoying after while. I'd much rather figure it out for myself than have the play interupted so much, or at least an option to turn it off.

review: Amazing game! Anyone that has played the original majesty will fall head over heels for this. It's an RTS that doesn't actually let you control your troops. It's more like you are the king and you see all that happens in your kingdom, order buildings to be constructed, set bounties to ENCOURAGE your troops(A.K.A. heroes)to do things like attack enemy buildings, protect your own buildings or explore a certain spot. It's an actually difficult game that takes a lot more concentration and strategy than you would first think. However there are multiple different stages that can be played and you can improve your strategy, rhythm by doing so. Something cool that was added in for Majesty 2 is the idea of the lords: for each land(or territory or stage whatever you wanna call them) that you conquer, you can "hire" one of the heroes you got there to be a lord. They keep whatever eqipment, experience and spells they aquire when you use them and you can hire them again on the other stages for a price. Better yet, there is no money sink. Once you have bought the game, you can buy expansions, but you don't have anything like "magic gems" to buy a load of in-game crap. Once you have the game, it's all you: skill, determination, and strategy will help you win.

review:
Absolument ADDICTIF ET INCONTOURNABLE !!!

J'ai acheté ce jeu a l'occasion d'une promotion steam sans grande ambition en me disant que j'allais l'abandonner rapidement...

Que nenni !!! j'ai tellement accroché au concept et graphismes simples (tout en etant tres attachant) 
ainsi qu'au doublage francais INTEGRAL et ses notes d'humour a la carambar 
que des que j'ai du temps devant moi je passe des soirees voir des jours dessus :D.... 
Il m'a meme fait adorer l'univers de Ardania , et fait aller sur le 1er volet sur mobile .

Le principe de primes pour inciter les heros a agir est tout simplement bien pensé bien qu'on se dise au debut que ca ne va pas aller tres loin en fait c'est vraiment ce qui fait le sel du jeu .

En anticipant les miseres qui tombent sur notre pauvre royaumes (les monstres donc !) celui ci se construit petit a petit
jusqu'a grouiller de vie (avec son lot de nuisances comme l'apparition des rats attaquants les villageois.
On se plait a donner titres de noblesse aux heros les plus meritants et on a toujours une petite peine quand l'un d'eux meurt,
au point que je les ressucite tous ^^" ...

Bref sous ses airs de petits jeux il vous fera passer de belles heures devant votre pc 
si vous aimez le style graphique a l'ancienne bien sur (style 2000-2005).

Bref je vous le conseille !!

review:
This game is much, but not a Kingdom Simulator. Thankfully, because that would have ruined the game. It is more of an overworld Dungeon Keeper where you build guilds in which you can recruit heroes and then they live there and walk through your town fighting and levelling up.
The flag system is interesting, because most of your heroes will not be heroically without a paycheck.
The only problem I have is that the difficulty sometimes is to hard and other times to easy.
Do not expect to have direct control over things, because you are the king. Think of this game as more of a mastermind game, where you set the board and the figures play by themselves.
If you are into that, buy it!
If you are into direct control and hate infinite spawns that pump out enemies until you destroy the spawn, then stay away!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012164188', 'num_games_owned': 1089, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1582451437}
review:
This is of course a sequel to [b]Majesty: The Fantasy Kingdom Sim[/b], just a collection with all the DLC (think expansion packs, not just small additions though there are a few). I recommend picking the original up if you can handle dated graphics, the gold edition is available on Steam as well but that's not what this review is for.

Like the original game you play as the King of Ardania, who with your trusty comedic aide/advisor you build a fairly simplistic kingdom of a market, blacksmith, guardhouses and various guilds to train Heroes. Heroes are the key to this game as they are the characters that will fight your battles and you have the most [i]influence[/i] over. Influence is the best word because you cannot directly command them to do anything, just merely suggest they do some tasks by setting bounties (attack, explore, defend) as well as a fear flag which while it isn't a bountie in the true sense, they work on the same mechanics.

The campaign chronicles the journey to become the undisputed King of Ardania, as time progressed from the first king (from the first game) each king has tried to secure their place in history with grander feats of bravery. Lets just say the last king didn't do so well and you should watch the opening cinematic to see the bravery your forebearers had. The campaign is missioned based and you generally need to complete each mission to progress to the next ones, they generally unlock one or two missions at the same time and for replay value the tutorial is completely optional. Be warned, it does start simple but you do get a large difficulty spike later.

I recommend [b]a[/b] Majesty game to anyone who is remotely interested in the premise of the game, this is a worthy sequel but the changes made sort of balance out the improvements made to make it equivalent to the original. The biggest difference from the original (for me) is most heroes will not respond to your bounties quickly unless you put some real money on them, not necessarily a bad thing because it does seem you get more gold income but it can be slightly annoying if you're used to the original. If you want this as an updated version of Majesty you won't be dissapointed, though you may find yourself wanting a bit more.
