author: {'steamid': '76561198023899327', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1367478000}
review:
First of all, this is not a simulation.  The game calls itself a Fantasy Kingdom simulator, but that's wrong.  Majesty 2 largely lacks the elements of a sim game.  If you're looking for a sim, look elsewhere.
This is an RTS.  It applies the same basic principles of RTS games: build buildings, acquire resources, build troops, fight.
To the game's credit, though, its RTS mechanics are fairly unique for the genre.
Instead of commanding troops directly, like you would in Command and Conquer, Starcraft, and to a lesser extent Kohan, you control them by trying to incentivize them.
So if you want an enemy destroyed, you post a quest flag on the enemy's base, along with a reward.  Your "heroes" (they are called heroes but they are both as numerous and as functional as troops might be in other RTS games) will then gravitate towards the flag, at a pace depending on the size of the reward offered.
There are diffferent kinds of quests to use, and different heroes have different preferences for them.  A ranger hero, for example, prefers exploration quests (basically just removing fog of war from the map, like you might do with an Observer or Zergling in Starcraft), but will still do other quests (with priorities based on reward).
So some people might find that interesting.
Unfortunately, most of the game consists of taking out "lairs."  Lairs are creep spawning buildings littered across the map.  Destroying lairs is important, because it generates revenue (much like in Warcraft III, where destroying as many creeps as possible was crucial to the early game- here, though, the entire length of a game requires you to destroy lairs).  There are many lairs.  The monsters they spawn are relentless.  There is no grace period at the beginning of the game for you to build up your base and army.  It is both difficult and tedious to fend off the constant assaults, while also staging your own attacks against lairs and AI opponents.  Compounding this is the fact that as your base grows, indestructible lairs spawn amongst your buildings.  These are the sewers and cemetaries.  The sewers endlessly spawn hordes of mutant rats (and you will get more than one sewer), and the cemetary spawns constant undead.  These are complete weaklings, and can't be taken care of by the paltry automated defenses available to you.  So you have to devote heroes (and gold, because heroes pretty much never go anywhere without gold) to kill off waves of enemies coming from within your own base as well as without.  This is very tedious.
You also have to ensure your heroes' survival, because they need to level up and acquire better equipment.  If they don't, they won't be strong enough to survive.  That's some catch, this catch 22.
You can bring in heroes from previous scenarios (these are called Lords), but they are extremely expensive and you can only have a maximum of four.
There are no difficulty settings in Majesty 2.  If you're thinking "Well, I can just play on Easy Mode," tough luck,  There isn't one.  There's no downgrading the crapstorm.
The story and setting are silly.  The game is intended to be humorous, but I didn't laugh at a single joke.  Maybe it's better in the original Russian, maybe I'm just a joyless git.  Some people find the game hilarious, I'm not one of them.  A staple of the game's humor is the odd take on the fantasy setting, and frequent jabs at the trope.  Barbarians are all Conan-types, complete with Germanic accents.  You never see Dwarven women.  Nearly everything is at least slightly silly.  Might be amusing for some, but not for me.

For those of you still interested but concerned about the difficulty, there is a fan-made campaign with adjustable difficulty settings out there.  I haven't tried it, and can't speak to its quality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025466397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1406859223}
review: People play games for many reasons.  I personally play them just to have fun.  This game was not fun for me.  At all.  Constant waves of enemies attacking your city, insanely powerful boss monsters which attack literally within 2 minutes of the last one, monster spawns in the middle of starting towns.  It's almost like the developers set out to make people who play this miserable, like they have some kind of vendetta against people who enjoyed the original Majesty.  I wish I could give this game a better review; I WANT to give it a better review.  I really can't though.  Nice concepts, but when you add an endless conga line of mobs running straight at your town from the beginning, it feels less like a kingdom sim and more like tower defense.  I didn't buy this game for tower defense.  If that is want you are looking for, go for it, otherwise ignore this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028635003', 'num_games_owned': 320, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 23610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14733, 'last_played': 1615109262}
review:
Stellt euch vor, ihr spielt ein Strategiespiel wie z.B.: "Age of Empires" oder "Command & Conquer",
baut diverse Gebäude ... Verteidigunsanlagen ... Kampf-Einheiten ... vergrößert eure Basis.
ABER ihr gebt eure Einheiten keine Befehle mehr, denn sie spielen von selbst!

Eure Einheiten entscheiden selbst,
|-> ob sie Kämpfen, Verteidigen, Erkunden
|-> oder sich ergeben, fliehen, schlafen ...

POSITIVES:
+ 4 unterschiedliche Kampagnen und 11 Einzelmissionen
+ Auf der Spieleverpackung steht "Monatelanger Spielspaß" - Bestätigt!
+ Kein Frust beim Verlieren, weil einfach das immerwieder Unterschiedliche Aufbauen Spaß macht!
Gewinnen ist was für Looser, ich sag ja nur "Spieler stirbt, Spieler verlässt das Spiel"
Zweck des Verlierens hier, ist es aus Fehlern zu lernen
und dies wird euch auch von eurem persönlichem Dienern gesagt.
+ Gute Steuerung und gute Kamerabewegung, inklusive +Zoom-
+ 5 Spielgeschwindigkeiten während des Spieles schnell umschaltbar
+ Schöne Grafik und Landschaftsgestaltung
+ Sehr gute Musik, Sounds und Spezialeffekte
+ Echt sehr gute Kampfanimationen und Fähigkeitsanimation
+ Viele unterschiedliche Helden und Fähigkeiten
+ Bei den Kämpfen zuschauen macht extrem Spaß
+ Viele Spezialfähigkeiten, Tränke, Items
+ Kein Maximum beim Level-Up der Einheiten
+ Namensgebung an Einheiten möglich, eigene Helden
+ Viele lustige Texte, Geschichten und Sprachausgabe: Komplett in Deutsch
+ Viele unterschiedliche Monster und Menschliche Feinde verfügbar
+ Zufallsprinzip der Monsternester und Höhlen aktivierbar
für immer wieder neue Abwechslung, es beeinträchtigt die Schwierigkeit !!!extrem!!!
+ Multiplayer-Modus, über das kostenlose Hamachi super
 
NEGATIVES:
- Es gibt keine wirkliche Storygeschichte
unwichtig ... ^^
- Keine Einstellung des Schwierigkeitsgrades
nicht anfängerfreundlich, aber schwer ist ja bekanntlich schön! Ich liebe es schwer! ^^
- Unter Option kann man "Keine Filme anzeigen" aktivieren,
macht man dies, werden trotzdem Filme angezeigt.
Ist zwar egal, weil man diese sofort per Klick überspringen kann,
aber der Button funktioniert halt nicht. Jaja ... auf sowas achte ich.
- Multiplayer Server offline, ihr braucht euch also nicht extra einen GameSpy-Account anlegen, wie es das Spiel sagt! Man kann aber mit dem kostenlosen Programm bei Chip.de "Hamachi" mit Freunden zusammenspielen, leider nur Player VS Player und  kein CO-OP, aber Spaß hat man hier allemal! Und der Multiplayer verfügt im Spiel selbst übrigens keinerlei Chat-Funktion!
- Angeblich laut "4Player-Testbericht" kleinere Ruckler im Spiel
Nicht bestätigt - Läuft alles flüssig! Hatte in meiner ganzen Spielzeit nicht einen Lag oder Absturz.
4Player.de: 83 / 100 Punkte gegegben
 
WICHTIG:
Ich habe mit Majesty2 schon viele Stunden verbracht,
und muss sagen, es grenzt echt sehr knapp an einem KAIZO-SPIEL !!!
(Wer nicht weiß, was ein KAIZO-SPIEL ist,
schaut euch mal auf YouTube "Super Mario" und "Kaizo Super Mario" an.
Dann seht ihr den Unterschied. ;-)
Ansonsten in kurzform: Das Spiel ist >>>EXTREM SCHWER<<< aber NICHT UNMÖGLICH

Ich bin in der Kampagne übrigens bis zur letzen Mission gekommen.
Wobei es Missionen gab, wo ich über 25 Spielstungen drangesessen habe.
Aber bei dem Drachen mit Abermillionen HP grenzt es dann doch an Betrug.
1 Drache vs 24 Einheiten! Wer gewinnt? Ich nicht ...
Aber ich probiere es weiter! :D
Ansonsten sage ich nur "KOMM DU ERSTMAL BIS DAHIN! HAHAHA !!!"
(Und ich wette, das keiner von EUCH (In meiner Freundesliste) es jemals schaffen wird!)
 
FAZIT: Wer auf Strategiespiele steht:
Scheißt auf Age of Empires ... scheißt auf Command & Conquer ...
Obwohl das eine davon auch schon geil ist ... aber egal.
Kauft euch Majesty2 und erobert die Welt von Ardania zurück !
KAUFT ES UND KLAUT DEN RATTENKÖNIG SEINEN GELIEBTEN KÄSE !!!

Süße Träume, Meine Freunde!
Grüne Hügel und Wiesen im drückendheißem Dschungel erwarten Euch!
Also vergesst eure Sonnencreme nicht!
Ach ja, und die Monster, die dort hausen ... natürlich.
Heißt sie WILLKOMMEN.

review:
If you like the campaign of Warcraft III, Age of Empires or specially Age of Mythology you will love this one. I can't believe a quality RTS lived under my radar for almost 5 years.

This game is like any other strategy game but with a small twist. They've changed the way you move your men and give tasks to a more realistic way, and for some reason they got it to work. It's filled with humor, it will gradually learn you the game and it  have 3 expansions.

How ever after running an local files update through steam it removed my progress. I'ts a lot of work to get back, changing a lot of files to get the game to recognize what levels are done, your saves and your saved heroes from after each level. There is also currently some kind fo bug that won't let you access expansions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004580302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3625, 'last_played': 1439517324}
review:
This is probably one of my favorite games, with your strategy having to shift depending on the quest/scenario parameters - so you never end up developing a cookie-cutter strat that works for every scenario.  Yes, it means you may frequently have to a mission in order to refine your plan, but that's part of what makes it fun, and ultimately rewarding when you succeed.

Although, I do admit, sometimes you really want to yell at your heroes for not doing exactly what you want them to, when you want them to!  But their varying response levels just add another dimension of challenge and resource management to the game.  

Very addicting, entertaining, and delightful strategy/simulation game.  Plus the Advisor makes a great narrator, adding a sense of whimsy and fun.

review:
A God game comparable to the greatest one, Dungeon Keeper, Majesty 2 has beautiful music and could be one of the best games you've ever played or repetitive and frustrating, depending on your tastes. 

It's reminiscent of any classic roleplaying game, except the usual player characters are NPCs, and you set the quests and build the cities that they rest and shop in. It is a pleasure to watch the heroes grow in strength, pop the health potions that they bought from you, learn new skills, work together, and sometimes (or often), die together.

Majesty 2 is one of those rare and valuable games that is more difficult than its predecessor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072175063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1500, 'last_played': 1386283092}
review:
This is a great game that takes a departure from stnadard RTS games in that you don't have direct control over your units. You start each level with a castle and you have to build various guilds and economic structures in order to grow your kingdom. You decide which buildings to build, which things to upgrade, and how many units to train. The only resource is money, and it is handled either throw your own economy of units buying things at the marketplace to improve their stats, or by building trading posts. Units will interact with buildings by buying better armor, potions, etc. and begin to level up as they face off against creatures that attack you kindgdom. You can manipulate your heroes by assigning reward flags to targets, setting explore flags, or setting defend flags. Each level is designed with a particular objective (kill a target, gather enough gold, defend for x number of days, etc)

There is lots of unit variety, from rogues, to archers, mages, warriors, and then high level units which have powerful abilities later on in the game. There are also lots of things to upgrade, and many unit combination to explore once you can build inns and form parties. Leveling your units is also satisfying as they learn powerful skills and maul their enemies in the most impressive and satisfying ways. This game is incredibly addicting once you get the hang of it, and missions easily span hours at a time. Graphically the game holds up great and things animate and look reasonably well. There is some nice humour thrown in for good measure with your advisor having a rather amusing sean-connory-like voice. Also your units say random things as they go about their business in your kingdom, so this game has quite a bit of charm. However, I will say that there isn't much of a story, but the mission scenarios feel varied enough with you having to fight all sorts of mystical creatures in intereting ways.  

As far as difficulty, about half way through the game it skyrockets. The premise of the game is to manage to build a starting kingdom with limited resources that can fend off attackers. Once you get comfortable and money starts rolling in you, you can amass a grand army and plow pretty much anything. The issue is that you have to become very clever with where you put guard towers, and were you position your marketplace/guilds. Especially in the later missions, older strategies won't work and you'll have to do a lot of trial and error to figure things out, ie. it almost becomes a puzzle game. This game is definitely not for the faint of heart and it gets really HARD. Reading guides online is sometimes the only way to progress (it's totally frustrating, but also totally worth it once you figure things out). In my case, I couldn't get passed only 2 missions, so I used a hack to get extra money at the start, which is another option to make certain missions more enjoyable. 

This collection comes with 4 games. The original majesty 2, 2 expansions which just add extra missions, and then the Monster Kingdom. The first 2 expansions ramp up the difficulty even more and I recommend staying away from them unless you really like this game. The last expansion swaps your human-like kingdom for a monster-kingom. The difficulty is much better balanced and makes for a better expeience. 

In sum, I have put in 25 hours over the course of 3 days into this game (it is hellishly addicting once you get going). In total there is probably 50+ hours packed into this package. I can heartily recommend giving this game a go, because it's an experience unlike any you've ever had. Just be prepared for the difficulty spike (so use those internets to your advantage).

review:
Same basic game as the first Majesty but there are some differences. If you’re not familiar with the first game, you are the king and you need to keep your kingdom safe by completing quests. Each quest has a difficulty level and set of starting parameters. In the first game you could take on one of these quests or set up your own quest. This feature is gone in Majesty 2. The graphics are considerably better as well. The quests themselves, however, are the same basic idea. I think there may actually be fewer quests.
All and all, still a good game. I might suggest getting it while it’s cheap.

review: Multiplayer is unfortunately no longer available, but this game has a long and entertaining, and even fairly challenging single player campaign. The advisor is hilarious, and the game has a fantastic sense of humor in general. It is also one of the most innovative RTS approaches I've ever seen. The idea is essentially that you have a bunch of heroes in your kingdom similar to those in a D&D game and you are the guy who puts rewards up for them to go on quests. Each character type has its own personality and you have to manipulate them accordingly in order to get anything done.

review:
Its what it says on tin - Fantasy Kingdom Sim - or to translate its "Theme Park" genre :)

You do not control units directly, you create infrastructure and hire your crew from asorted fantasy cliche. And influence theirs behaviour with creating reward flags. So for example you click on Wolf cave and write 500 gold reward to anyone who will help to destry it [This can be done with one powerfull hero or multiple weaker ones will party up to task and share]
Every hero class have its personality, thief will go to suicide scout mission if price is right, wariors are likely to run into defense or clerics will much more likely participate in elimination of undeads and healing other heroes

Do not be fooled though.
Trough few tutorial missions seems easy and simple game becomes pretty hardcore later, still not its game where even multiple restarts do not frustrate me as its the way how to learn what and when to counter to survive in given scenario.

Graphics and GUI is nice and well thought out so you do not have hard time to find what you need.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997873533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1217, 'last_played': 1702508316}
review:
I can easily say this is my favorite game. Even when I don't feel like playing anything else, I can play a round of Majesty. Some folks like to call out the game's difficulty like it were a bad thing. I won't pretend like it isn't hard, and that I don't routinely restart missions, but that just means you actually have to strategize and plan ahead. I consider it fun! And because of the "Randomize" feature (on top of several campaigns + stand-alone missions), the game has incredible replayability. I do notice that sometimes the game crashes when I go to save, which isn't a problem for me because I've completed everything already, but for new players, I should warn you.

I recently bought the Collection on Steam because it includes DLC that is no longer being sold. It's a good deal!

author: {'steamid': '76561197980711569', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1351839600}
review:
While this game definitely has enough thought and love put into it to appeal to some players, I found my expierence ultimately frustrating right up to 'Quit To Desktop.'

Majesty 2 is a fantasy RTS. You have a base, you have enemies, you have units and production buildings. A lot of the makings of this game are familiar to anyone who has played any sort of PC RTS game.

It contrasts harshly, though, with its RTS kin by taking a simulator-approach to control, much more in the camps of Sim City and Tropico than the combat RTSes that you're probably familiar with. This is the primary problem with the game, though. A central, defining mechanic, is that you cannot command units. You can't really command anyone to do anything. Much more like commanding humans in the real world, you can more or less dump breadcrumbs an incentives at objectives, and hope that units will wander along and do your bidding. This works very well in the mentioned simulator titles, because the game's goals are very loosely time-sensitive, and often the challenge you are attempting to defeat is an effeciency quota, or a highscore. It becomes problematic when your objectives are to not be slaughtered by the skeletons that are tearing your castle down.

Placing a reward miles away from your base at an enemy dungeon is the only way to get adventurers to meander over there and eliminate the threat. But, the amount of response time between placing a reward and your little lemming's arrival is so significant, huge events can occur before one adventurer sets eyes on the lair.

Like, say, an army of skeletons.
And, if this were to occur, I am sure in the real world, a lord would just recall his lair-bounty in favor of base defense. Well, no such luck. Even dumping a larger pot of gold at on your doorstep doesn't seem to help, so often you will encounter odd situations like the destruction of your base, as you watch your would-be defenders weakly beating goblins in the woods somewhere.

I am sure that these problems could be overcome with proper diligence, stragety, and patience, portioning miniscule rewards for objectives and just waiting their completion out. But, when exploring the game's mechanics and worlds, Majesty 2 tends to respond to any sort of failure with slow, plodding frustration, and the rewards for playing effectively feel so anticlimactic that after a very short period of time, I couldn't take anymore. I dumped all my gold in the woods; The skeletons can have my castle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000265305', 'num_games_owned': 1082, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1646151451}
review:
The Majesty series is something that i've allways really loved. It's an RTS with a twist - while you have controll over how your town grows, placing down buildings and managing it's defence and economy, this is an indirect controll game. You see, as king of the fantasy realm of Ardania, you have at your disposal a legion of heroes; wizards, fighters, rangers, clerics, wizards and rogues, all brave masters of their proffession... and all completley unwilling to do anything gratis. They're heroes, of course, and anyone who's played an RPG can tell you that Stalwart Defenders Of The Land won't even get up in the morning without a stack of gold and 20xp.

 So, in order to controll your heroes, you build inns for them to gather in, and fill them with shadowy cloaked figures in corners for them to accept quests off of and, most importantly, set aside a big stack of cash to pay them with. You'll need them, too... you can't go 10 feet out of town without being mauled by bears or attacked by skeletons, and more than just rats lurk in the sewers under the city...

The collection also includes the game's expansions and all the dlc, which are great fun. The Monster Kingdom DLC lets you play as the king of the monsters, fighting back against the heroes you controll during the standard campaign with monstrous heroes of your own, while Battles of Ardania adds an entire extra campaign. While these are great fun, they are very much sequels to the main campaign - they are monstrously hard, and should only really be attempted by an experienced player.

Difficulty, in fact, is something that comes up a lot in Majesty - while it starts quite gentle, it gets very hard very fast, and so might not be suitable for casual gamers. I would really encourage players to stick with it. Even when it looks like your city is doomed, just stick with it. Something might happen to turn the tide, and it 'aint over until it's over.

But other than that, Majesty is one of my favorite games out there. The games mechanics are great fun, it's hard but challenging, so you feel fantastic once you beat a level, and the game's humour is top notch. It doesnt take itself seriously, but never goes over the top into just stupid humour. Highly reccomended.

review: Maybe it's like falling in love, we don't have a lot of control over who steals our hearts - the same is true of games.  Sometimes upopular games that get no more than a passing 'meh' from the masses are the ones that we fall in love with.  The Majesty series had that effect on me.  I can think of very few games that demanded my time and attention as much as these did (and still can).  I'm definitely ready for Majesty 3, I hope it's in the works or at least conceptualized.  Essentially, you create, and then the little folks that begin populating your creations take over from there, acting as autonomous little citizens of your kingdom.  Addicting, challenging, a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047460864', 'num_games_owned': 3164, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 23380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23219, 'last_played': 1590167199}
review:
[b]Well made RTS, not that easy, with independent heroes, obstinate enemies, a lot of humour and an epic soundtrack.[/b]

Majesty 2 is a real-time fantasy strategy game unique in its genre. Each game has its own campaign, divided in several maps. Each mission has its own objective(s) and secondary quests, for example : gather enough gold in the given time, kill the dragon and retrieve the artifact, train a wizard to level 35, destroy your enemy's castle, etc. You can randomize the map (locations of the monsters dens, trading posts, etc) to increase the difficulty of the mission, but the game is rather difficult already. The more you progress in the campaign, the more difficult it gets, until you'll probably have to load from time to time or restart a mission if you had a bad start. If you want more, there are also around 10 single missions that you can try and a game editor that allows you to create your own maps.

First of all, as every ruler worthy of the name, you own a castle that you have to defend at any cost : if it is destroyed, it's game over. To help you with the constructions, peasants will build their houses around ; up to you to protect them in return for their hard work. Then, your Majesty, you should build other required structures such as towers to defend your kingdom, a marketplace to keep the economy running by offering potions and accessories among others, a blacksmith to equip your heroes, an inn where people can rest, gather and create parties, etc. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1419795733

Now, the heroes ! You have to build the corresponding guild to recruit a hero, knowing that you can have 3 units per guild. You can count on warriors, rogues, rangers, clerics, wizards, elves and dwarves, each having specific stats and behaviour. The tricky part is that you don't get to control your heroes, you have to persuade them ; that's what the flags are for. There are 4 types of flags : attack, defend, explore and warning flag. Every time you place a flag, you have to set a gold amount to attract your heroes as well ; if nobody answers to your call, try increasing the reward. As every other building, you can upgrade the guilds too, in order to unlock special abilities and spells. If by misfortune one of your heroes dies, you can of course train a new one, but it's best to resurrect him thanks to the graveyard. Note that the price increases at each level and the graveyard also spawns skeletons and various undeads that will attack your kingdom.

And then there are the temples, that you can build if you upgrade your castle to the level three. Each temple allows you to recruit 2 special units and more spells for you to use. For example, if you build a Temple of Agrela, you can recruit 2 priestesses level 1 or train two already existing clerics in exchange for an important amount of gold. There are also 2 spells that you can unlock, one to resurrect dead heroes for 750 gold, the other one being an AOE healing spell. 

[u]If you're hesitating, I'd suggest to buy the bundle (Majesty 2 Collection) if you can : it's less expensive than buying Majesty 2 and then the DLCs.[/u]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1419955066

[b]Majesty 2[/b] :
It all starts when King Leonard, staring at his ancestor's portraits, realizes that he's the only one in the lineage who hasn't faced a great danger and prevailed yet. Obviously, he decides to do something really stupid to fix it : he gathers the mages to summon a great demon. What could possibliy go wrong ? Thankfully, the (funny) advisor finds you, the last living with royal blood in your veins. It won't be easy to prove your worth, convince the people, defeat your opponents, gather the artifacts and slain the Barlog, but you're destined to become the Returned King of Ardania, through the 16 missions (including the tutorial).

[b]Kingmaker expansion[/b] :
Kingmaker is a pretty hard DLC that I won't suggest to play before finishing the main game. There are 8 missions but it's advanced and expert difficulty, so even if you've already completed the first campaign and know how the game works, you're still gonna have a hard time through those intense maps full of strong opponents and multiple enemy waves. This DLC takes place after you defeated the Barlog : your kingdom prospers and the culture flourishes, but at night, people start noticing shiny creepy eyes luring in the dark... The Goblins and their poison are back and as you progress against the goblin-shamans, you'll discover that Grum-Gog himself, the goblin God of Plague, is involved ! Up to you to protect your lands and its inhabitants from the green skins, your Majesty.

[b]Battles of Ardania expansion[/b] : 
Battles of Ardania is the most difficult expansion in my humble opinion ; everyone who has played the Minotaur invasion mission will probably agree with me ! This DLC evolves around a conspiracy story and a - little too ambitious - mage who made a deal with a wearwolf and dreams of becoming a god. You will have the pleasure of playing the 8 available missions - that is, if you manage to beat them. Prepare yourself for the most challenging quests that will require a lot of determination, strategy and loading ! But in the end, it's always worth it ; you can't let the people of Ardania down, your Majesty !

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1439347537

[b]Monster Kingdom expansion[/b] :
Monster Kingdom is my favourite DLC of Majesty 2. The Conclave betrayed the King - yourself - and stole the Artifacts. You and your adviser have no other choice but to flee and seek for new allies, for an army to return against the Conclave and the False King they summoned. Your only option is an army of monsters - yes, the monsters your previously opposed. You will have to convince them to fight by your side in return for equals rights, among other things, once you reclame the crown and the throne. Which means that your buildings and inhabitants will be monstrous as well : vampires as tax collector, gnomes as builders - unlike the peasants we're used to, the gnomes fight back at least ! - etc. The funniest part is the new units : Goblin archers, Goblin spearmen, Liches, Koatls, Minotaurs, Ratmen Robbers and Werewolves. All of them have new abilities, upgrades and new Majesty's spells to discover. There are 10 missions in this DLC, from advanced to expert mode ; strangely I found most advanced maps more difficult than the expert ones. Every kind of unit and the mission descriptions are fully voiced and the voice acting of the monster units is the best of the game in my humble opinion - after years without playing I still remembered a lot of lines. If you want to buy one and only one DLC for Majesty 2, get this one without hesitation.

The first time I discovered Majesty 2 was in 2011 (it was the very first game I added to my Steam account so maybe there's a bit of nostaliga here) and I loved it. Then I played it in 2013 again, and now in 2018 and still enjoyed it as on day one. I think this game is challenging yet amusing and differs from the other strategy games that I've played so far. I also like the work and details on the description of the quests and the advisor's tirades, there's always something funny about it. I just regret the lack of multiplayer content, because despite the multi-player tag on Steam, it's really limited : 8 existing missions, 1v1, 2v2, 2v1 or FFA. Maybe one day I'll create a co-op mission to test the game editor myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996859673', 'num_games_owned': 2099, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1411127721}
review:
Real fun, most of the people hate the changes made in Majesty 2 but I really couldn't play the first one, not only because of the dated graphics but because the UI in majesty 2 is much much better. The "flag rewards" are all on one hud, so is the palace button, the buildings are organized in categories, etc. So what is Majesty 2? You essentially build your kingdom, recruit some heroes and give away some bounties. Heroes will decide if they want to goof around, do some adventuring on their own (very rare but possible), maybe do some shopping in the blacksmith you upgraded for them (and hey, if they spend money, you get it back with taxes) or just follow your "bounties". That's right, you don't control them, but you can tell them "Hey I'll pay you 300 gold for taking out that wolves' den". In Majesty 2 you can make parties too, seems strange that a King should concern itself with it, but hey, better me than a stupid AI, so you make your parties balanced and off you go for adventure.
Haven't tried multiplayer yet, but I heard Internet servers are down and only LAN can be played, but anyway, I really like this game, there is enough rpg elements like abilities, levels, equips, stats for your heroes to love the customization and rts elements (more like city management rts but yeah). The last great part about this, which is highly personal, is that the game is in Ardania, the fantasy world and culture that I learned to love through Warlock - Master of the Arcane. All the bad rewievs didn't give me much hope for this game, but it's awesome, mods heavily recommended (they balance quite some things, I use Majesty 2 Reloaded).

review:
I like this game as its a very interesting combination of RTS and City Sim. You don't actually control your units but instead build a kingdom to attract, equip and power-up heroes who go on "quests" that you "sponsor". You also can gain many different spells to directly influence the battle.

There are many hero types and they all have certain personality types that effects how they behave i.e. rangers love to scout the map and rogues are easy to bribe to get them to do anything. 

Game is HARD though so if you are the type to give up or become frustrated easily then you may want to pass.

review:
Highly Recommended! 9/10 (see below)

This game is FUN! If you like both RTS (Real-Time Strategy) games and fantasy games, you should love this game! Absolutely terrific! It's an RTS where you entice your RPG heroes to do quests for you by offering monetary rewards for their services. You can then sell them better weapons, potions, and enchanted jewelry to help them in their battles. Do yourself a favor and buy this game! :D

Despite the phenomenal gameplay that this title offers, there is one drawback. The game has a few 'difficulty' bugs. I've heard that saving a game can corrupt it in a way that makes it harder when you reload it. But personally I've just been hit with some of the levels being much harder sometimes then they are other times. The frustrating thing is that some of the levels were already made to be difficult, so it can get really hard. Most of the time the game is not affected so I still highly recommend the game, but not a full 10/10.

review: This is a unique interpretation of the classic rpg/strategy game. You don't actually control units yourself, but must instead entice them to do what you want through bounties and rewards. Some of the level difficulties do not scale well for the game's progress and the AI is randomized, so the game can end up feeling incredibly difficult at times. If you have the patience and enjoy a challenge in rpg/strategy, I would recommend giving Majesty 2 a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055036618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 40238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20990, 'last_played': 1708615654}
review:
Excellent jeux, suite améliorée de Majesty qui sublime encore le gameplay en l'adaptant et le modernisant. Pour les fans de stratégie, de héros et de gestion.

Ici, on ne dirige pas de héro, mais on gere un royaume en y installant des structures pour entrainer et améliorer les héros de toutes catégories : guerriers, magiciens, voleurs, paladins, nains, elfes,...

Après un apprentissage convenable, on pense pouvoir gagner facilement les défis proposés, mais il n'en est rien. La difficulté augmente rapidement, passé un cap. Et la, il faut s'acharner, trouver la bonne stratégie et avoir un peu de chance. L'or est le nerf de la guerre. De fait, les frustrations sont grandes après moult échecs mais la victoire fait un bien fou.

Et après quelques temps, on s'y remet. J'adore

review: This is an underappreciated series. It's a RTS - sort of - where you only control building construction and a "reward system". Through constructing buildings in your fantasy city, you attract adventurers. Warriors, rogues, clerics, mages, etc. They earn gold by completing quests you give them, like attacking monsters and clearing lairs. In turn they spend that gold in your buildings, buying items such as healing potions and weapon/armour upgrades, which in turn gives you gold to buy or upgrade new buildings. It's a unique concept for an RTS. The game is a little dated now and it doesn't quite realize it's full potential, which is a shame. I'd love to see Blizzard make a version of Majesty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991483156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1333263600}
review:
This is an RTS. Sorta... More realistic than what I would believe a game should be.

Instead of the a-typical select units, tell units to go attack in a flank formation, command mid-battle to turn the tide, etc, etc- it's more of a system to entice your units into what you want them to do. You set a reward on a monster, and then put a bounty on it's head. That is an amazingly cool idea- but in practice it doesn't work out so well.

I had set my flag, and set the bounty to 100. No one would go kill this monster... I set the bounty to 600, nothing. Finally around the 2000 (more than a 1/3 of all the money I had available) mark someone wanted to try it. They promptly died, so one more decided to try it. They died. There isn't really a symbolence of strategy here as I watched each unit die to just one, the very first at that, monster.

At 4,000 I finally got more than one unit to go and they spent more time running away together than fighting. And for 2/3 of my kingdom- it was awful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020270276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5675, 'last_played': 1387324177}
review:
Love this game.  The original Majesty was one of the first computer games I ever played and its sequel lives up to my memories of the original.  The gameplay is awesome, but can get repetitive after 40 hours of play.  Thankfully there are tons of levels and scenarios which each offer new challenges.

Seriously though.  Goblin experts are annoying as hell.

edit: For those whining about the difficulty, if you use the hall of lords properly and understand how to construct balanced parties, the game is a breeze. The only mission I had to repeat was the last one. I really don't see what all the fuss is about.

review: Majesty 2 is a interesting combination between real time strategy with heavy low fantasy medieval role playing game elements.  The thorough tutorial does a great job of teaching you the basics of the game and the interface and graphics are crisp and bright.  Fans of games like Warcraft or Command and Conquer should feel right at home in Majesty 2, while the role playing elements offer something even for the casual RTS fan.  The Steam Overlay works and widescreen resolutions are supported making the Majesty 2 Collection a welcome addition to any strategy gamer's library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006636652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1331967600}
review:
It's not perfect, but it's damn fun.
You rule a kingdom, you construct Guilds and watch your Heroes (Rogues, Mages, Warriors, Priests etc.)  run around and kill stuff and protect the cities you build. Caravans, marketplace, blacksmith and much more make up your cities. Earn gold and upgrade them for better gear and potions for your heroes. You can also research spells that cost gold to cast, but helps you manage your kingdom. That healingspell at  just the right time can make or break a fight.
There's a lot of AI in the game that has to be fine-tuned to make it work. It's ok, but of course not perfect. I do hope for a M3 with even more of the same, just better!
It's cheap, and well worth the cost vs. hours-of-fun ratio.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971033905', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1693922478}
review:
A fun game where you watch your little Heroes act like.. well heroes.

At times it can be frustrating and gameplay can be alittle repetitive.

But a must-buy still in my opinion. 

Paradox Interactive has done a great job at preserving a game from its predecessor (Majesty)

Positives:
+ Fun concept of having heroes as npcs who do their own little thing.
+ Graphics are impressive for a game which is quite dated

Negatives(If any):
- Punishing Difficulty - can be a turn-off to some players.
- Encryption of the database files such that players cannot cheat - as much as i don't encourage cheating - it should be allowed to let players get through frustrating moments.

review: Majesty 2 Collection - for a mere 19 euro we get a complete pack: Majesty 2 AND also all the 3 updates, including the one that allows us to play with MONSTERS kingdom, if we ever get bored of the regular one :) Everything that we loved in Majesty 1 we have in Majesty 2, in some cases things have been made easier, but overall the combat is harder, although to compensate we have better tools to influence actions of our heroes. IF you didn't play Majesty 1, you'll love this game. If you did, you won't get dissapointed - and that's saying a lot :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197976335974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1313478000}
review:
A unique mixture of City Builder, RTS and RPG.

Build guild halls and economic buildings to support your town. Recruit Heroes consisting of typical RPG/MMO builds. Hire warriors as tanks, healers for support, archers for ranged strikes ect.

Heroes run off thier own AI. Wandering the kingdom looking for things to do. Hunting, supporting, defending, looting and more, depending on thier personality. Buy training upgrades, open a marketplace and blacksmith shop where your heroes will visit to spend thier loot.

Use your gold to place bounties encouraging heroes to follow your quests.Bounties consist of an exploration flag, attack flag, defense flag and fear flag (for keeping weak heroes away from stong monsters), Attempt to bribe your forces to do your bidding. Some personalities being more succeptible than others to certain tasks.

All heroes gain XP and Levels. Each mission choose 1 hero to keep. Buy him again on later levels from the Hall of Lords, retaining thier previous level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006641138', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 12187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4913, 'last_played': 1702863334}
review:
$20 bucks for hours of gameplay. Relatively quick to play for many maps making it a good one when you've just got an hour of so. Pretty much unique as far as games go; I don't know of anything else like Majesty.

Downsides: Later campaigns are hard and I generally just play the single map scenarios after a certain point. Monster Kingdom can only be played in campaign mode, which is a shame.

His Majesty is sure you will like this game. *Winces again as the palace shakes* Uh I should probably get back to my job.
